section_id: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence

hints.label: rem-representation-independence
hints.title: Representation Independence
hints.content:
1008: :label: rem-representation-independence
1009: 
1010: The Fractal Set uses:
1011: - **Scalars in nodes**: Fitness $\Phi$, energies $E_{\text{kin}}, U$, statistics $\mu_\rho, \sigma_\rho$
1012: - **Spinors in edges**: Velocity $\psi_v$, forces $\psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}}, \psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}}, \ldots$
1013: 
1014: This is a **storage format choice**. The underlying Markov chain dynamics operate on the **numerical state vector** $Z_k = (X_k, V_k)$.
1015: 
1016: **Why spinors?**
1017: - Gauge theory formulation (cf. `12_gauge_theory_adaptive_gas.md`)
1018: - Emergent geometry (cf. `08_emergent_geometry.md`)
1019: - QFT interpretation (cf. `13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md`)
hints.section: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence
hints.raw_directive:
1005: **Answer:** **No.** Convergence is a property of the **numerical values** $(x_i, v_i)$, not their representation.
1006: 
1007: :::{prf:remark} Representation Independence
1008: :label: rem-representation-independence
1009: 
1010: The Fractal Set uses:
1011: - **Scalars in nodes**: Fitness $\Phi$, energies $E_{\text{kin}}, U$, statistics $\mu_\rho, \sigma_\rho$
1012: - **Spinors in edges**: Velocity $\psi_v$, forces $\psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}}, \psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}}, \ldots$
1013: 
1014: This is a **storage format choice**. The underlying Markov chain dynamics operate on the **numerical state vector** $Z_k = (X_k, V_k)$.
1015: 
1016: **Why spinors?**
1017: - Gauge theory formulation (cf. `12_gauge_theory_adaptive_gas.md`)
1018: - Emergent geometry (cf. `08_emergent_geometry.md`)
1019: - QFT interpretation (cf. `13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md`)
1020:

hints.label: rem-cloning-in-drift
hints.title: Cloning in the Drift
hints.content:
1031: :label: rem-cloning-in-drift
1032: 
1033: The adaptive and viscous forces contain cloning effects:
1034: 
1035: $$
1036: \begin{aligned}
1037: \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, Z) &= \epsilon_F \nabla V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i) \\
1038: \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, Z) &= \nu \sum_{j \neq i} K_\rho(x_i, x_j) (v_j - v_i)
1039: \end{aligned}
1040: 
1041: $$
1042: 
1043: These forces **depend on other walkers' states** via the empirical measure $f_k$ and pairwise coupling.
1044: 
1045: The **Keystone Principle** ({prf:ref}`lem-quantitative-keystone`) guarantees that:
1046: - High-error walkers experience high cloning pressure (encoded in $V_{\text{fit}}$)
1047: - This contracts positional variance
hints.section: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence
hints.raw_directive:
1028: **Answer:** The antisymmetry is the **standard fitness difference** that drives cloning in {prf:ref}`lem-quantitative-keystone`. It's already accounted for in the force fields.
1029: 
1030: :::{prf:remark} Cloning in the Drift
1031: :label: rem-cloning-in-drift
1032: 
1033: The adaptive and viscous forces contain cloning effects:
1034: 
1035: $$
1036: \begin{aligned}
1037: \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, Z) &= \epsilon_F \nabla V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i) \\
1038: \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, Z) &= \nu \sum_{j \neq i} K_\rho(x_i, x_j) (v_j - v_i)
1039: \end{aligned}
1040: 
1041: $$
1042: 
1043: These forces **depend on other walkers' states** via the empirical measure $f_k$ and pairwise coupling.
1044: 
1045: The **Keystone Principle** ({prf:ref}`lem-quantitative-keystone`) guarantees that:
1046: - High-error walkers experience high cloning pressure (encoded in $V_{\text{fit}}$)
1047: - This contracts positional variance
1048:

hints.label: thm-fractal-set-n-particle-equivalence
hints.title: Equivalence of Fractal Set and N-Particle Properties
hints.content:
1065: :label: thm-fractal-set-n-particle-equivalence
1066: 
1067: Let $\mathcal{F} = (\mathcal{N}, E_{\text{CST}} \cup E_{\text{IG}})$ be the Fractal Set and let $\{Z_k\}_{k \geq 0}$ be the N-particle discrete-time Markov chain from {prf:ref}`def-swarm-state-vector`. Then:
1068: 
1069: **1. Lossless state reconstruction:**
1070: 
1071: For each node $n_{i,t} \in \mathcal{N}$, there exists a unique walker state $(x_i(t), v_i(t)) \in Z_t$ that can be reconstructed from the Fractal Set data, and conversely, each walker state at timestep $t$ generates exactly one node in $\mathcal{N}$ during simulation. This establishes a bijection $\mathcal{N}_t \leftrightarrow Z_t$ for states at each fixed time $t$.
1072: 
1073: **2. Reconstruction of phase space:**
1074: 
1075: Given $\mathcal{F}$, the full phase space trajectory can be reconstructed via:
1076: 
1077: $$
1078: x_i(t) = x_i(0) + \sum_{s=0}^{t-1} \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{\Delta x}(n_{i,s}, n_{i,s+1})]
1079: 
1080: $$
1081: 
1082: $$
1083: v_i(t) = \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{v,t}(n_{i,t-1}, n_{i,t})]
1084: 
1085: $$
1086: 
1087: where the spinor-to-vector map extracts the $\mathbb{R}^d$ vector from its spinor encoding $\psi \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$.
1088: 
1089: **3. Transfer of symmetries:**
1090: 
1091: The symmetry structure on $\mathcal{F}$ ({prf:ref}`thm-sn-su2-lattice-qft`) corresponds to algorithmic symmetries of the N-particle system. The Fractal Set has a three-tier symmetry hierarchy:
1092: 
1093: $$
1094: G_{\text{total}} = S_N^{\text{discrete}} \times \text{SU}(2)_{\text{weak}}^{\text{local}} \times \text{U}(1)_{\text{fitness}}^{\text{global}}
1095: 
1096: $$
1097: 
1098: where $S_N$ (permutation group) is the **fundamental discrete gauge symmetry**, while SU(2) and U(1) are **emergent** symmetries in the continuum limit.
1099: 
1100: **S_N permutation symmetry** ↔ **Walker indistinguishability**:
1101: 
1102: The **fundamental gauge symmetry** of the algorithm is invariance under walker label permutations. For any permutation $\sigma \in S_N$:
1103: 
1104: $$
1105: \mathcal{S} = (w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_N) \sim \sigma \cdot \mathcal{S} = (w_{\sigma(1)}, w_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, w_{\sigma(N)})
1106: 
1107: $$
1108: 
1109: This discrete gauge symmetry gives rise to **braid group topology** $\pi_1(\mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}) \cong B_N$ ({prf:ref}`thm-sn-braid-holonomy`). Closed loops in configuration space have **discrete holonomy** $\text{Hol}(\gamma) \in S_N$, representing the net permutation of walkers after traversing the loop.
1110: 
1111: **Physical consequence**: All algorithmic observables must be $S_N$-invariant - they depend on unordered sets of walkers, not specific labels. The $S_N$ holonomy is the **fundamental discrete gauge observable**, analogous to how Wilson loops probe continuous gauge connections (but distinct from them - $S_N$ holonomy is a permutation, not a matrix trace).
1112: 
1113: **Global U(1) fitness symmetry** ↔ **Fitness conservation**:
1114: 
1115: The **global** (not gauged) U(1) symmetry ({prf:ref}`thm-u1-fitness-global`) acts by uniform phase rotation on all diversity amplitudes:
1116: 
1117: $$
1118: \psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})} \to e^{i\alpha} \psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})}, \quad \alpha \in [0, 2\pi) \text{ (same } \alpha \text{ for all i)}
1119: 
1120: $$
1121: 
1122: This corresponds to **invariance under global fitness shifts** $\Phi(x) \mapsto \Phi(x) + c$ in the N-particle system. The diversity companion probability:
1123: 
1124: $$
1125: P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) = \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}{\sum_{k'} \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}
1126: 
1127: $$
1128: 
1129: depends only on positions and velocities (via $d_{\text{alg}}$), **not** on absolute fitness values, making it invariant under global fitness shifts.
1130: 
1131: **Conserved charge (Noether)**: Global U(1) symmetry implies conservation of fitness current $J_{\text{fitness}}^\mu = \sum_i \text{Im}(\psi_i^* \partial^\mu \psi_i)$, analogous to baryon number conservation in particle physics.
1132: 
1133: **Local SU(2) weak isospin symmetry** ↔ **Approximate role exchange in cloning**:
1134: 
1135: The SU(2) doublet structure $|\Psi_{ij}\rangle = |↑\rangle \otimes |\psi_i\rangle + |↓\rangle \otimes |\psi_j\rangle$ ({prf:ref}`thm-su2-interaction-symmetry`) corresponds to an **approximate algorithmic symmetry** where the cloning dynamics are nearly invariant under exchange of cloner and target roles. This near-invariance is quantified by the ratio:
1136: 
1137: $$
1138: \frac{P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)}{P_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)} \approx 1 + O(\Phi_j - \Phi_i)
1139: 
1140: $$
1141: 
1142: The symmetry becomes **exact** in the limit of vanishing fitness differences:
1143: 
1144: $$
1145: \lim_{\Phi_j - \Phi_i \to 0} \frac{P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)}{P_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)} = 1
1146: 
1147: $$
1148: 
1149: **Physical meaning**: On the fitness-degenerate submanifold, walkers are interchangeable with respect to weak isospin transformations, and the dynamics exhibit exact SU(2) invariance under mixing of cloner and target roles.
1150: 
1151: **4. Conserved and derived quantities:**
1152: 
1153: **Energy conservation in BAOAB**: The total energy $H_{\text{total}}(Z_k) = \sum_i [E_{\text{kin},i} + U(x_i)]$ stored in nodes satisfies:
1154: 
1155: $$
1156: \mathbb{E}[H_{\text{total}}(Z_{k+1}) | Z_k] = H_{\text{total}}(Z_k) + O(\Delta t)
1157: 
1158: $$
1159: 
1160: up to dissipation from friction and stochastic forcing.
1161: 
1162: This corresponds to **energy flow balance** in the Fractal Set: Energy changes along CST edges equal the work done by forces stored in edge spinors:
1163: 
1164: $$
1165: E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t+1}) - E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t}) = \int_{t}^{t+1} \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}}] \cdot \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{v}] \, ds
1166: 
1167: $$
1168: 
1169: **Derived statistical observables**: Localized statistical moments $\mu_\rho(n), \sigma_\rho(n)$ stored in nodes are **not conserved quantities** but rather **functionals of IG edge data**. They satisfy:
1170: 
1171: $$
1172: \mu_\rho[f_k, \Phi, x_i(t)] = \frac{\sum_{j \in A_k(t)} w_{ij}(\rho) \Phi_j}{\sum_{j \in A_k(t)} w_{ij}(\rho)}
1173: 
1174: $$
1175: 
1176: where the localization weights $w_{ij}(\rho) = K_\rho(x_i - x_j)$ are stored in IG edges. The node scalars $\mu_\rho(n_{i,t})$ are **computed observables derived from** the empirical measure $f_k(t)$ encoded in the graph structure, not fundamental quantities. This establishes **correspondence** between node-stored statistics and the underlying N-particle distribution.
1177: 
1178: **Proof:**
1179: 
1180: **Part 1 (Bijection):** By construction ({prf:ref}`def-node-spacetime`), each node $n_{i,t}$ has unique walker ID $i$ and timestep $t$, establishing a one-to-one correspondence with $(x_i(t), v_i(t)) \in Z_t$.
1181: 
1182: **Part 2 (Reconstruction):** Follows directly from {prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-reconstruction` items 1-2. The position is obtained by integrating displacement spinors along CST edges, and velocity is directly stored in CST edge spinors.
1183: 
1184: **Part 3 (Symmetries):**
1185: 
1186: **S_N permutation proof:** The N-particle algorithm treats walkers as **indistinguishable particles** with arbitrary labels. Any physical observable must be invariant under label permutations $\sigma \in S_N$. For example:
1187: 
1188: - Cloning probability depends on walker states, not labels: $P_{\text{clone}}(\sigma(i) \to \sigma(j) | \sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j | \mathcal{S})$
1189: - Fitness histogram is an unordered set: $\{V_{\text{fit}}(i) : i \in A_t\}$ is $S_N$-invariant
1190: - Diversity distances are symmetric: $d_{\text{alg}}(i, j) = d_{\text{alg}}(j, i)$
1191: 
1192: In the Fractal Set, this fundamental gauge redundancy manifests as **braid holonomy**. When walkers exchange positions during dynamics, their worldlines form braids in spacetime. Closed loops $\gamma$ in configuration space have holonomy $\text{Hol}(\gamma) \in S_N$, measuring the net permutation acquired.
1193: 
1194: **Discrete holonomy**: For a closed path in CST+IG, the holonomy is computed via the braid homomorphism $\rho: B_N \to S_N$. This **discrete gauge structure** is fundamental - all other symmetries (U(1), SU(2)) are emergent in the continuum limit. Unlike continuous Wilson loops (which are matrix traces), the $S_N$ holonomy is a discrete permutation, making this a hybrid discrete-continuous gauge theory.
1195: 
1196: **Global U(1) proof:** The diversity companion selection follows a Gibbs distribution. From the Fractal Set specification, the probability is:
1197: 
1198: $$
1199: P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) = \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}{\sum_{k' \in A_t \setminus \{i\}} \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}
1200: 
1201: $$
1202: 
1203: The algorithmic distance is defined as:
1204: 
1205: $$
1206: d_{\text{alg}}(i, k)^2 = \|x_i - x_k\|^2 + \lambda_v \|v_i - v_k\|^2
1207: 
1208: $$
1209: 
1210: where $\lambda_v$ is a constant weighting parameter. **Crucially, $d_{\text{alg}}$ depends only on positions and velocities, NOT on fitness values $\Phi(x_i), \Phi(x_k)$.**
1211: 
1212: Under a global fitness shift $\Phi(x) \mapsto \Phi(x) + c$ for constant $c \in \mathbb{R}$:
1213: 
1214: $$
1215: \begin{aligned}
1216: d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2 &= \|x_i - x_k\|^2 + \lambda_v \|v_i - v_k\|^2 \\
1217: &\quad \text{(unchanged, as positions and velocities are independent of fitness labeling)} \\
1218: \Rightarrow P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) &= \frac{\exp(-d_{\text{alg}}^2/(2\epsilon_d^2))}{\sum_{k'} \exp(-d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2/(2\epsilon_d^2))} \\
1219: &\quad \text{(invariant)}
1220: \end{aligned}
1221: 
1222: $$
1223: 
1224: The U(1) phase $\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})} = -d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2/(2\epsilon_d^2 \hbar_{\text{eff}})$ is likewise invariant. **Global** phase transformations $\psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})} \to e^{i\alpha} \psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})}$ (same $\alpha$ for all $i, k$) leave all observables invariant:
1225: 
1226: $$
1227: \left|\psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})}\right|^2 = P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) \quad \text{(global U(1) invariant)}
1228: 
1229: $$
1230: 
1231: This is **not a gauge symmetry** - there is no dynamical gauge field. The phases $\theta_{ik}$ are fixed by algorithmic distances. It's a **global symmetry** like baryon number conservation, giving a conserved Noether current $J_{\text{fitness}}^\mu$.
1232: 
1233: **SU(2) proof:** The cloning amplitude $\Psi(i \to j)$ factorizes ({prf:ref}`def-cloning-amplitude-factorization`) as:
1234: 
1235: $$
1236: \Psi(i \to j) = A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} \cdot K_{\text{eff}}(i, j)
1237: 
1238: $$
1239: 
1240: where $A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} = \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{clone})}(j|i)} e^{i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU(2)})}}$ is the bare SU(2) vertex and $K_{\text{eff}}$ is the U(1)-dressed effective kernel.
1241: 
1242: An SU(2) transformation $U \in \text{SU}(2)$ acts on the isospin doublet $(|\psi_i\rangle, |\psi_j\rangle)^T$ as a rotation, mixing cloner and target roles. In the N-particle system, the amplitude ratio:
1243: 
1244: $$
1245: \frac{\Psi(i \to j)}{\Psi(j \to i)} = \frac{A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} \cdot K_{\text{eff}}(i, j)}{A_{ji}^{\text{SU(2)}} \cdot K_{\text{eff}}(j, i)}
1246: 
1247: $$
1248: 
1249: The SU(2) vertex satisfies $A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} \propto \exp(i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU(2)})})$ where the phase depends on algorithmic distance, which is **symmetric** under $(i,j)$ exchange. However, the probability amplitude $\sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{clone})}(j|i)}$ contains **fitness asymmetry** through the cloning score $S(i,j,k,m) = V_{\text{fit}}(i|k) - V_{\text{fit}}(j|m)$.
1250: 
1251: Therefore:
1252: 
1253: $$
1254: \frac{\Psi(i \to j)}{\Psi(j \to i)} = \exp\left(\frac{i}{\hbar_{\text{eff}}} [S(i,j,k,m) - S(j,i,m,k)] + O(\Phi_j - \Phi_i)\right)
1255: 
1256: $$
1257: 
1258: In the limit $\Phi_j - \Phi_i \to 0$, the fitness differences vanish and the ratio approaches unity, establishing **exact SU(2) symmetry on the fitness-degenerate submanifold**.
1259: 
1260: **Part 4 (Conserved and derived quantities):**
1261: 
1262: **Energy conservation:** From the BAOAB O-step ({prf:ref}`def-baoab-kernel`), the velocity update includes stochastic forcing:
1263: 
1264: $$
1265: v^{(2)} = e^{-\gamma \Delta t} v^{(1)} + \sqrt{\frac{1}{\gamma}(1 - e^{-2\gamma \Delta t})} \, \Sigma_{\text{reg}} \xi
1266: 
1267: $$
1268: 
1269: where $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$. The kinetic energy evolves as:
1270: 
1271: $$
1272: \begin{aligned}
1273: E_{\text{kin}}(v_{k+1}) &= \frac{1}{2}\|v_{k+1}\|^2 \\
1274: &= \frac{1}{2}\|v_k + \Delta t \, \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} + \sqrt{\Delta t} \, \Sigma_{\text{reg}} \tilde{\xi}\|^2 \\
1275: &\quad \text{(where } \tilde{\xi} \text{ is the rescaled noise)} \\
1276: &= \frac{1}{2}\|v_k\|^2 + \Delta t \, v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} + \sqrt{\Delta t} \, v_k \cdot \Sigma_{\text{reg}} \tilde{\xi} \\
1277: &\quad + \frac{\Delta t^2}{2}\|\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}\|^2 + \frac{\Delta t}{2}\|\Sigma_{\text{reg}} \tilde{\xi}\|^2 + O(\Delta t^{3/2})
1278: \end{aligned}
1279: 
1280: $$
1281: 
1282: Taking expectations over the noise $\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\xi}] = 0, \mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\xi}\|^2] = d$:
1283: 
1284: $$
1285: \begin{aligned}
1286: \mathbb{E}[E_{\text{kin}}(v_{k+1}) | v_k] &= E_{\text{kin}}(v_k) + \Delta t \, v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} \\
1287: &\quad + \frac{\Delta t}{2} \text{Tr}(\Sigma_{\text{reg}} \Sigma_{\text{reg}}^T) + O(\Delta t^2)
1288: \end{aligned}
1289: 
1290: $$
1291: 
1292: The $O(\Delta t)$ terms are:
1293: - $v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}$: **Power from forces** (work done)
1294: - $\frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^2)$: **Stochastic heating**
1295: 
1296: The $O(\Delta t^2)$ terms include friction dissipation $-\gamma \Delta t \|v_k\|^2$ and higher-order force-noise coupling. For the **total energy** $H_{\text{total}} = \sum_i [E_{\text{kin},i} + U(x_i)]$:
1297: 
1298: $$
1299: \mathbb{E}[H_{\text{total}}(Z_{k+1}) | Z_k] = H_{\text{total}}(Z_k) + \Delta t \, (\text{heating} - \text{dissipation}) + O(\Delta t^2)
1300: 
1301: $$
1302: 
1303: where the $O(\Delta t)$ term represents the **balance between stochastic forcing and friction**, not exact conservation.
1304: 
1305: The term $v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}$ equals:
1306: 
1307: $$
1308: v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} = \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_v] \cdot \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}}]
1309: 
1310: $$
1311: 
1312: using the spinor representation. The node scalars $E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t+1})$ and $E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t})$ store the energies, while the CST edge spinors $\psi_v, \psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}}, \psi_{\Sigma_{\text{reg}}}$ enable computing the energy flow components.
1313: 
1314: **Derived statistical observables:** The localized mean $\mu_\rho[f_k, \Phi, x_i]$ is computed from the empirical measure $f_k(t)$:
1315: 
1316: $$
1317: f_k(t) = \frac{1}{k} \sum_{j \in A_k(t)} \delta_{(x_j(t), v_j(t))}
1318: 
1319: $$
1320: 
1321: where $A_k(t) = \{j : s(n_{j,t}) = 1\}$ is determined from node status flags. The localization kernel $K_\rho(x_i - x_j)$ stored in IG edges provides the weighting:
1322: 
1323: $$
1324: \mu_\rho[f_k, \Phi, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \Phi_j, \quad w_{ij}(\rho) = \frac{K_\rho(x_i - x_j)}{\sum_{m \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i - x_m)}
1325: 
1326: $$
hints.section: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence
hints.raw_directive:
1062: :::
1063: 
1064: :::{prf:theorem} Equivalence of Fractal Set and N-Particle Properties
1065: :label: thm-fractal-set-n-particle-equivalence
1066: 
1067: Let $\mathcal{F} = (\mathcal{N}, E_{\text{CST}} \cup E_{\text{IG}})$ be the Fractal Set and let $\{Z_k\}_{k \geq 0}$ be the N-particle discrete-time Markov chain from {prf:ref}`def-swarm-state-vector`. Then:
1068: 
1069: **1. Lossless state reconstruction:**
1070: 
1071: For each node $n_{i,t} \in \mathcal{N}$, there exists a unique walker state $(x_i(t), v_i(t)) \in Z_t$ that can be reconstructed from the Fractal Set data, and conversely, each walker state at timestep $t$ generates exactly one node in $\mathcal{N}$ during simulation. This establishes a bijection $\mathcal{N}_t \leftrightarrow Z_t$ for states at each fixed time $t$.
1072: 
1073: **2. Reconstruction of phase space:**
1074: 
1075: Given $\mathcal{F}$, the full phase space trajectory can be reconstructed via:
1076: 
1077: $$
1078: x_i(t) = x_i(0) + \sum_{s=0}^{t-1} \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{\Delta x}(n_{i,s}, n_{i,s+1})]
1079: 
1080: $$
1081: 
1082: $$
1083: v_i(t) = \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{v,t}(n_{i,t-1}, n_{i,t})]
1084: 
1085: $$
1086: 
1087: where the spinor-to-vector map extracts the $\mathbb{R}^d$ vector from its spinor encoding $\psi \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$.
1088: 
1089: **3. Transfer of symmetries:**
1090: 
1091: The symmetry structure on $\mathcal{F}$ ({prf:ref}`thm-sn-su2-lattice-qft`) corresponds to algorithmic symmetries of the N-particle system. The Fractal Set has a three-tier symmetry hierarchy:
1092: 
1093: $$
1094: G_{\text{total}} = S_N^{\text{discrete}} \times \text{SU}(2)_{\text{weak}}^{\text{local}} \times \text{U}(1)_{\text{fitness}}^{\text{global}}
1095: 
1096: $$
1097: 
1098: where $S_N$ (permutation group) is the **fundamental discrete gauge symmetry**, while SU(2) and U(1) are **emergent** symmetries in the continuum limit.
1099: 
1100: **S_N permutation symmetry** ↔ **Walker indistinguishability**:
1101: 
1102: The **fundamental gauge symmetry** of the algorithm is invariance under walker label permutations. For any permutation $\sigma \in S_N$:
1103: 
1104: $$
1105: \mathcal{S} = (w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_N) \sim \sigma \cdot \mathcal{S} = (w_{\sigma(1)}, w_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, w_{\sigma(N)})
1106: 
1107: $$
1108: 
1109: This discrete gauge symmetry gives rise to **braid group topology** $\pi_1(\mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}) \cong B_N$ ({prf:ref}`thm-sn-braid-holonomy`). Closed loops in configuration space have **discrete holonomy** $\text{Hol}(\gamma) \in S_N$, representing the net permutation of walkers after traversing the loop.
1110: 
1111: **Physical consequence**: All algorithmic observables must be $S_N$-invariant - they depend on unordered sets of walkers, not specific labels. The $S_N$ holonomy is the **fundamental discrete gauge observable**, analogous to how Wilson loops probe continuous gauge connections (but distinct from them - $S_N$ holonomy is a permutation, not a matrix trace).
1112: 
1113: **Global U(1) fitness symmetry** ↔ **Fitness conservation**:
1114: 
1115: The **global** (not gauged) U(1) symmetry ({prf:ref}`thm-u1-fitness-global`) acts by uniform phase rotation on all diversity amplitudes:
1116: 
1117: $$
1118: \psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})} \to e^{i\alpha} \psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})}, \quad \alpha \in [0, 2\pi) \text{ (same } \alpha \text{ for all i)}
1119: 
1120: $$
1121: 
1122: This corresponds to **invariance under global fitness shifts** $\Phi(x) \mapsto \Phi(x) + c$ in the N-particle system. The diversity companion probability:
1123: 
1124: $$
1125: P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) = \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}{\sum_{k'} \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}
1126: 
1127: $$
1128: 
1129: depends only on positions and velocities (via $d_{\text{alg}}$), **not** on absolute fitness values, making it invariant under global fitness shifts.
1130: 
1131: **Conserved charge (Noether)**: Global U(1) symmetry implies conservation of fitness current $J_{\text{fitness}}^\mu = \sum_i \text{Im}(\psi_i^* \partial^\mu \psi_i)$, analogous to baryon number conservation in particle physics.
1132: 
1133: **Local SU(2) weak isospin symmetry** ↔ **Approximate role exchange in cloning**:
1134: 
1135: The SU(2) doublet structure $|\Psi_{ij}\rangle = |↑\rangle \otimes |\psi_i\rangle + |↓\rangle \otimes |\psi_j\rangle$ ({prf:ref}`thm-su2-interaction-symmetry`) corresponds to an **approximate algorithmic symmetry** where the cloning dynamics are nearly invariant under exchange of cloner and target roles. This near-invariance is quantified by the ratio:
1136: 
1137: $$
1138: \frac{P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)}{P_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)} \approx 1 + O(\Phi_j - \Phi_i)
1139: 
1140: $$
1141: 
1142: The symmetry becomes **exact** in the limit of vanishing fitness differences:
1143: 
1144: $$
1145: \lim_{\Phi_j - \Phi_i \to 0} \frac{P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)}{P_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)} = 1
1146: 
1147: $$
1148: 
1149: **Physical meaning**: On the fitness-degenerate submanifold, walkers are interchangeable with respect to weak isospin transformations, and the dynamics exhibit exact SU(2) invariance under mixing of cloner and target roles.
1150: 
1151: **4. Conserved and derived quantities:**
1152: 
1153: **Energy conservation in BAOAB**: The total energy $H_{\text{total}}(Z_k) = \sum_i [E_{\text{kin},i} + U(x_i)]$ stored in nodes satisfies:
1154: 
1155: $$
1156: \mathbb{E}[H_{\text{total}}(Z_{k+1}) | Z_k] = H_{\text{total}}(Z_k) + O(\Delta t)
1157: 
1158: $$
1159: 
1160: up to dissipation from friction and stochastic forcing.
1161: 
1162: This corresponds to **energy flow balance** in the Fractal Set: Energy changes along CST edges equal the work done by forces stored in edge spinors:
1163: 
1164: $$
1165: E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t+1}) - E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t}) = \int_{t}^{t+1} \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}}] \cdot \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{v}] \, ds
1166: 
1167: $$
1168: 
1169: **Derived statistical observables**: Localized statistical moments $\mu_\rho(n), \sigma_\rho(n)$ stored in nodes are **not conserved quantities** but rather **functionals of IG edge data**. They satisfy:
1170: 
1171: $$
1172: \mu_\rho[f_k, \Phi, x_i(t)] = \frac{\sum_{j \in A_k(t)} w_{ij}(\rho) \Phi_j}{\sum_{j \in A_k(t)} w_{ij}(\rho)}
1173: 
1174: $$
1175: 
1176: where the localization weights $w_{ij}(\rho) = K_\rho(x_i - x_j)$ are stored in IG edges. The node scalars $\mu_\rho(n_{i,t})$ are **computed observables derived from** the empirical measure $f_k(t)$ encoded in the graph structure, not fundamental quantities. This establishes **correspondence** between node-stored statistics and the underlying N-particle distribution.
1177: 
1178: **Proof:**
1179: 
1180: **Part 1 (Bijection):** By construction ({prf:ref}`def-node-spacetime`), each node $n_{i,t}$ has unique walker ID $i$ and timestep $t$, establishing a one-to-one correspondence with $(x_i(t), v_i(t)) \in Z_t$.
1181: 
1182: **Part 2 (Reconstruction):** Follows directly from {prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-reconstruction` items 1-2. The position is obtained by integrating displacement spinors along CST edges, and velocity is directly stored in CST edge spinors.
1183: 
1184: **Part 3 (Symmetries):**
1185: 
1186: **S_N permutation proof:** The N-particle algorithm treats walkers as **indistinguishable particles** with arbitrary labels. Any physical observable must be invariant under label permutations $\sigma \in S_N$. For example:
1187: 
1188: - Cloning probability depends on walker states, not labels: $P_{\text{clone}}(\sigma(i) \to \sigma(j) | \sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j | \mathcal{S})$
1189: - Fitness histogram is an unordered set: $\{V_{\text{fit}}(i) : i \in A_t\}$ is $S_N$-invariant
1190: - Diversity distances are symmetric: $d_{\text{alg}}(i, j) = d_{\text{alg}}(j, i)$
1191: 
1192: In the Fractal Set, this fundamental gauge redundancy manifests as **braid holonomy**. When walkers exchange positions during dynamics, their worldlines form braids in spacetime. Closed loops $\gamma$ in configuration space have holonomy $\text{Hol}(\gamma) \in S_N$, measuring the net permutation acquired.
1193: 
1194: **Discrete holonomy**: For a closed path in CST+IG, the holonomy is computed via the braid homomorphism $\rho: B_N \to S_N$. This **discrete gauge structure** is fundamental - all other symmetries (U(1), SU(2)) are emergent in the continuum limit. Unlike continuous Wilson loops (which are matrix traces), the $S_N$ holonomy is a discrete permutation, making this a hybrid discrete-continuous gauge theory.
1195: 
1196: **Global U(1) proof:** The diversity companion selection follows a Gibbs distribution. From the Fractal Set specification, the probability is:
1197: 
1198: $$
1199: P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) = \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}{\sum_{k' \in A_t \setminus \{i\}} \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2}{2\epsilon_d^2}\right)}
1200: 
1201: $$
1202: 
1203: The algorithmic distance is defined as:
1204: 
1205: $$
1206: d_{\text{alg}}(i, k)^2 = \|x_i - x_k\|^2 + \lambda_v \|v_i - v_k\|^2
1207: 
1208: $$
1209: 
1210: where $\lambda_v$ is a constant weighting parameter. **Crucially, $d_{\text{alg}}$ depends only on positions and velocities, NOT on fitness values $\Phi(x_i), \Phi(x_k)$.**
1211: 
1212: Under a global fitness shift $\Phi(x) \mapsto \Phi(x) + c$ for constant $c \in \mathbb{R}$:
1213: 
1214: $$
1215: \begin{aligned}
1216: d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2 &= \|x_i - x_k\|^2 + \lambda_v \|v_i - v_k\|^2 \\
1217: &\quad \text{(unchanged, as positions and velocities are independent of fitness labeling)} \\
1218: \Rightarrow P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) &= \frac{\exp(-d_{\text{alg}}^2/(2\epsilon_d^2))}{\sum_{k'} \exp(-d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2/(2\epsilon_d^2))} \\
1219: &\quad \text{(invariant)}
1220: \end{aligned}
1221: 
1222: $$
1223: 
1224: The U(1) phase $\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})} = -d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2/(2\epsilon_d^2 \hbar_{\text{eff}})$ is likewise invariant. **Global** phase transformations $\psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})} \to e^{i\alpha} \psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})}$ (same $\alpha$ for all $i, k$) leave all observables invariant:
1225: 
1226: $$
1227: \left|\psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})}\right|^2 = P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) \quad \text{(global U(1) invariant)}
1228: 
1229: $$
1230: 
1231: This is **not a gauge symmetry** - there is no dynamical gauge field. The phases $\theta_{ik}$ are fixed by algorithmic distances. It's a **global symmetry** like baryon number conservation, giving a conserved Noether current $J_{\text{fitness}}^\mu$.
1232: 
1233: **SU(2) proof:** The cloning amplitude $\Psi(i \to j)$ factorizes ({prf:ref}`def-cloning-amplitude-factorization`) as:
1234: 
1235: $$
1236: \Psi(i \to j) = A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} \cdot K_{\text{eff}}(i, j)
1237: 
1238: $$
1239: 
1240: where $A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} = \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{clone})}(j|i)} e^{i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU(2)})}}$ is the bare SU(2) vertex and $K_{\text{eff}}$ is the U(1)-dressed effective kernel.
1241: 
1242: An SU(2) transformation $U \in \text{SU}(2)$ acts on the isospin doublet $(|\psi_i\rangle, |\psi_j\rangle)^T$ as a rotation, mixing cloner and target roles. In the N-particle system, the amplitude ratio:
1243: 
1244: $$
1245: \frac{\Psi(i \to j)}{\Psi(j \to i)} = \frac{A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} \cdot K_{\text{eff}}(i, j)}{A_{ji}^{\text{SU(2)}} \cdot K_{\text{eff}}(j, i)}
1246: 
1247: $$
1248: 
1249: The SU(2) vertex satisfies $A_{ij}^{\text{SU(2)}} \propto \exp(i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU(2)})})$ where the phase depends on algorithmic distance, which is **symmetric** under $(i,j)$ exchange. However, the probability amplitude $\sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{clone})}(j|i)}$ contains **fitness asymmetry** through the cloning score $S(i,j,k,m) = V_{\text{fit}}(i|k) - V_{\text{fit}}(j|m)$.
1250: 
1251: Therefore:
1252: 
1253: $$
1254: \frac{\Psi(i \to j)}{\Psi(j \to i)} = \exp\left(\frac{i}{\hbar_{\text{eff}}} [S(i,j,k,m) - S(j,i,m,k)] + O(\Phi_j - \Phi_i)\right)
1255: 
1256: $$
1257: 
1258: In the limit $\Phi_j - \Phi_i \to 0$, the fitness differences vanish and the ratio approaches unity, establishing **exact SU(2) symmetry on the fitness-degenerate submanifold**.
1259: 
1260: **Part 4 (Conserved and derived quantities):**
1261: 
1262: **Energy conservation:** From the BAOAB O-step ({prf:ref}`def-baoab-kernel`), the velocity update includes stochastic forcing:
1263: 
1264: $$
1265: v^{(2)} = e^{-\gamma \Delta t} v^{(1)} + \sqrt{\frac{1}{\gamma}(1 - e^{-2\gamma \Delta t})} \, \Sigma_{\text{reg}} \xi
1266: 
1267: $$
1268: 
1269: where $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$. The kinetic energy evolves as:
1270: 
1271: $$
1272: \begin{aligned}
1273: E_{\text{kin}}(v_{k+1}) &= \frac{1}{2}\|v_{k+1}\|^2 \\
1274: &= \frac{1}{2}\|v_k + \Delta t \, \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} + \sqrt{\Delta t} \, \Sigma_{\text{reg}} \tilde{\xi}\|^2 \\
1275: &\quad \text{(where } \tilde{\xi} \text{ is the rescaled noise)} \\
1276: &= \frac{1}{2}\|v_k\|^2 + \Delta t \, v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} + \sqrt{\Delta t} \, v_k \cdot \Sigma_{\text{reg}} \tilde{\xi} \\
1277: &\quad + \frac{\Delta t^2}{2}\|\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}\|^2 + \frac{\Delta t}{2}\|\Sigma_{\text{reg}} \tilde{\xi}\|^2 + O(\Delta t^{3/2})
1278: \end{aligned}
1279: 
1280: $$
1281: 
1282: Taking expectations over the noise $\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\xi}] = 0, \mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\xi}\|^2] = d$:
1283: 
1284: $$
1285: \begin{aligned}
1286: \mathbb{E}[E_{\text{kin}}(v_{k+1}) | v_k] &= E_{\text{kin}}(v_k) + \Delta t \, v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} \\
1287: &\quad + \frac{\Delta t}{2} \text{Tr}(\Sigma_{\text{reg}} \Sigma_{\text{reg}}^T) + O(\Delta t^2)
1288: \end{aligned}
1289: 
1290: $$
1291: 
1292: The $O(\Delta t)$ terms are:
1293: - $v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}$: **Power from forces** (work done)
1294: - $\frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^2)$: **Stochastic heating**
1295: 
1296: The $O(\Delta t^2)$ terms include friction dissipation $-\gamma \Delta t \|v_k\|^2$ and higher-order force-noise coupling. For the **total energy** $H_{\text{total}} = \sum_i [E_{\text{kin},i} + U(x_i)]$:
1297: 
1298: $$
1299: \mathbb{E}[H_{\text{total}}(Z_{k+1}) | Z_k] = H_{\text{total}}(Z_k) + \Delta t \, (\text{heating} - \text{dissipation}) + O(\Delta t^2)
1300: 
1301: $$
1302: 
1303: where the $O(\Delta t)$ term represents the **balance between stochastic forcing and friction**, not exact conservation.
1304: 
1305: The term $v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}$ equals:
1306: 
1307: $$
1308: v_k \cdot \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}} = \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_v] \cdot \text{spinor-to-vector}[\psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}}]
1309: 
1310: $$
1311: 
1312: using the spinor representation. The node scalars $E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t+1})$ and $E_{\text{kin}}(n_{i,t})$ store the energies, while the CST edge spinors $\psi_v, \psi_{\mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}}, \psi_{\Sigma_{\text{reg}}}$ enable computing the energy flow components.
1313: 
1314: **Derived statistical observables:** The localized mean $\mu_\rho[f_k, \Phi, x_i]$ is computed from the empirical measure $f_k(t)$:
1315: 
1316: $$
1317: f_k(t) = \frac{1}{k} \sum_{j \in A_k(t)} \delta_{(x_j(t), v_j(t))}
1318: 
1319: $$
1320: 
1321: where $A_k(t) = \{j : s(n_{j,t}) = 1\}$ is determined from node status flags. The localization kernel $K_\rho(x_i - x_j)$ stored in IG edges provides the weighting:
1322: 
1323: $$
1324: \mu_\rho[f_k, \Phi, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \Phi_j, \quad w_{ij}(\rho) = \frac{K_\rho(x_i - x_j)}{\sum_{m \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i - x_m)}
1325: 
1326: $$
1327:

hints.label: cor-fractal-set-complete-representation
hints.title: Fractal Set as Complete Algorithmic Representation
hints.content:
1332: :label: cor-fractal-set-complete-representation
1333: 
1334: The Fractal Set $\mathcal{F}$ is **informationally and dynamically complete** for the N-particle Adaptive Gas algorithm:
1335: 
1336: **1. Informational completeness**: Every scalar, spinor, and graph structure element in $\mathcal{F}$ corresponds to a unique quantity or operation in the N-particle system (Reconstruction Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-reconstruction`).
1337: 
1338: **2. Dynamical completeness**: Every symmetry and conservation law in the N-particle system has a unique representation in $\mathcal{F}$ ({prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-n-particle-equivalence`).
1339: 
1340: **3. Convergence equivalence**: The discrete-time Markov chain generating $\mathcal{F}$ converges to the same long-term distribution as the continuous SDE, up to $O(\Delta t)$ discretization error ({prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-ergodicity`, {prf:ref}`thm-weak-convergence-invariant`).
hints.section: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence
hints.raw_directive:
1329: :::
1330: 
1331: :::{prf:corollary} Fractal Set as Complete Algorithmic Representation
1332: :label: cor-fractal-set-complete-representation
1333: 
1334: The Fractal Set $\mathcal{F}$ is **informationally and dynamically complete** for the N-particle Adaptive Gas algorithm:
1335: 
1336: **1. Informational completeness**: Every scalar, spinor, and graph structure element in $\mathcal{F}$ corresponds to a unique quantity or operation in the N-particle system (Reconstruction Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-reconstruction`).
1337: 
1338: **2. Dynamical completeness**: Every symmetry and conservation law in the N-particle system has a unique representation in $\mathcal{F}$ ({prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-n-particle-equivalence`).
1339: 
1340: **3. Convergence equivalence**: The discrete-time Markov chain generating $\mathcal{F}$ converges to the same long-term distribution as the continuous SDE, up to $O(\Delta t)$ discretization error ({prf:ref}`thm-fractal-set-ergodicity`, {prf:ref}`thm-weak-convergence-invariant`).
1341:

hints.label: rem-spinors-necessary
hints.title: Why Spinors Are Necessary
hints.content:
1346: :label: rem-spinors-necessary
1347: 
1348: **Question:** Could we store vectors $v \in \mathbb{R}^d$ directly instead of spinors $\psi \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$?
1349: 
1350: **Answer:** For **reconstruction** purposes, yes - vectors suffice. But for **gauge theory interpretation** and **emergent QFT formulation**, spinors are essential:
1351: 
1352: 1. **Frame independence**: Spinors transform covariantly under rotations without requiring a preferred basis.
1353: 2. **Geometric naturalness**: Spinors are the fundamental representation of the Lorentz/rotation group.
1354: 3. **Gauge connections**: The U(1) and SU(2) phases $\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})}, \theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU(2)})}$ act on spinor phases, not vector components.
1355: 4. **Fermionic structure**: Spinors enable antisymmetric Green's functions in the continuum limit.
1356: 5. **Clifford algebra**: Spinor formalism naturally encodes the geometric product structure underlying the viscous coupling.
hints.section: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence
hints.raw_directive:
1343: :::
1344: 
1345: :::{prf:remark} Why Spinors Are Necessary
1346: :label: rem-spinors-necessary
1347: 
1348: **Question:** Could we store vectors $v \in \mathbb{R}^d$ directly instead of spinors $\psi \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$?
1349: 
1350: **Answer:** For **reconstruction** purposes, yes - vectors suffice. But for **gauge theory interpretation** and **emergent QFT formulation**, spinors are essential:
1351: 
1352: 1. **Frame independence**: Spinors transform covariantly under rotations without requiring a preferred basis.
1353: 2. **Geometric naturalness**: Spinors are the fundamental representation of the Lorentz/rotation group.
1354: 3. **Gauge connections**: The U(1) and SU(2) phases $\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})}, \theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU(2)})}$ act on spinor phases, not vector components.
1355: 4. **Fermionic structure**: Spinors enable antisymmetric Green's functions in the continuum limit.
1356: 5. **Clifford algebra**: Spinor formalism naturally encodes the geometric product structure underlying the viscous coupling.
1357:

hints.label: rem-antisymmetric-ig-fermionic
hints.title: Antisymmetric IG Edges and Fermionic Statistics
hints.content:
1362: :label: rem-antisymmetric-ig-fermionic
1363: 
1364: The **directed antisymmetric** structure of IG edges:
1365: 
1366: $$
1367: V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = \Phi_j - \Phi_i = -V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)
1368: 
1369: $$
1370: 
1371: implies that IG edges are **oriented** by fitness differences. This has two interpretations:
1372: 
1373: **1. Algorithmic interpretation (this document):** Cloning is driven by fitness gradients. Walkers with higher fitness attract cloning events.
1374: 
1375: **2. QFT interpretation** (`13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md`): The antisymmetry enables **fermionic Green's functions**:
1376: 
1377: $$
1378: G_F(i, j) = \langle \psi(i) \bar{\psi}(j) \rangle = -G_F(j, i)
1379: 
1380: $$
1381: 
1382: where $\psi(i)$ is a fermionic field operator at node $n_i$.
1383: 
1384: In the continuum limit $N \to \infty, \Delta t \to 0$, the antisymmetric IG structure becomes a **fermionic propagator** with Grassmann-valued path integral. This is a **precursor** to fermionic statistics, not full fermions (walkers are distinguishable).
hints.section: ## 6. Fractal Set Specifics: Data Representation and Convergence
hints.raw_directive:
1359: :::
1360: 
1361: :::{prf:remark} Antisymmetric IG Edges and Fermionic Statistics
1362: :label: rem-antisymmetric-ig-fermionic
1363: 
1364: The **directed antisymmetric** structure of IG edges:
1365: 
1366: $$
1367: V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = \Phi_j - \Phi_i = -V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)
1368: 
1369: $$
1370: 
1371: implies that IG edges are **oriented** by fitness differences. This has two interpretations:
1372: 
1373: **1. Algorithmic interpretation (this document):** Cloning is driven by fitness gradients. Walkers with higher fitness attract cloning events.
1374: 
1375: **2. QFT interpretation** (`13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md`): The antisymmetry enables **fermionic Green's functions**:
1376: 
1377: $$
1378: G_F(i, j) = \langle \psi(i) \bar{\psi}(j) \rangle = -G_F(j, i)
1379: 
1380: $$
1381: 
1382: where $\psi(i)$ is a fermionic field operator at node $n_i$.
1383: 
1384: In the continuum limit $N \to \infty, \Delta t \to 0$, the antisymmetric IG structure becomes a **fermionic propagator** with Grassmann-valued path integral. This is a **precursor** to fermionic statistics, not full fermions (walkers are distinguishable).
1385:
